docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Regarding ''Waiting for Mammograms'' (March 10): The problem with mammogram reimbursements by managed care organizations is only a minor factor in the current accessibility crisis. The bigger issue, I believe, has to do with the nonreimbursements. As a physician whose practice is 90 percent insurance based, I find that a significant number of claims come back ''denied'' or reimbursed below the contracted fee.

headline.main: Denied Claims A Factor in Mammograms

docs.abstract: Dr Steven Y Park letter on March 10 article holds bigger issue with mammograms is claims denied or underreimbursed by managed-care insurance firms

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A prospective reader of ''Gracefully Insane,'' Alex Beam's portrayal of the McLean Hospital of the 1950's and 60's, might benefit from elaboration on Holly Brubach's review (Feb. 24). As a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, I played a significant role at McLean in that era, and I was involved in the treatment of some of the people mentioned. McLean was not, as the book apparently depicts, a kind of five-star hotel catering to the whims of affluent people. A large proportion of the patient population was composed of middle-class individuals subsidized by a health insurance system that was far more beneficent in its attitude toward mental illness than it is today. I was chairman of the committee that often granted substantial rate reductions to people who were short on funds. The wards were more like seedy college dormitories than hotels, and those patients who were well enough to leave the ward ate in a relatively unattractive cafeteria. What is most important, however, is the absurdity of the implication that highly accomplished people who are not seriously disturbed would choose to vacation in a mental hospital, or that what was done to them in the guise of treatment was thoughtless and often harmful. In numerous instances the excellent treatment the hospital afforded seriously disturbed individuals, by thoughtful, dedicated clinicians, ''cured'' or significantly ameliorated their illnesses so that they were able to leave the hospital and lead the kind of constructive and creative lives that subsequently gained them public recognition. Michael Robbins, M.D. Amherst, Mass.
docs.abstract: Dr Michael Robbins letter on Holly Brubach's February 24 review of Gracefully Insane: The Rise and Fall of America's Premier Mental Hospital by Alex Beam (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time, significant numbers of doctors are refusing to take new Medicare patients, saying the government now pays them too little to cover the costs of caring for the elderly. Medicare cut payments to doctors by 5.4 percent this year. The government estimates that under current law, the fees paid for each medical service will be reduced in each of the next three years, for a total decrease of 17 percent from 2002 to 2005.

headline.main: Many Doctors Shun Patients With Medicare

docs.abstract: Growing numbers of doctors are refusing to take new Medicare patients, saying government now pays them too little to cover costs of caring for elderly; Medicare cut payments to doctors by 5.4 percent this year, and government estimates that under current law fees paid for each medical service will be reduced in each of next three years, for total decrease of 17 percent from 2002 to 2005; health policy experts say cuts could make it more difficult for elderly people to find doctors just as need increases with aging of population; total Medicare spending rose 24 percent in last five years, to $238 billion in 2001; nearly $41 billion of total was for doctors' services; now Congress is considering expanding program to add prescription drug benefits; Bush administration says any increases in payments to some providers must be offset by cuts in payments to others; photo (L)
docs.snippet: For the first time, significant numbers of doctors are refusing to take new Medicare patients, saying the government now pays them too little to cover the costs of caring for the elderly.    Medicare cut payments to doctors by 5.4 percent this year....

docs.lead_paragraph: Like wine cognoscenti, the more knowledgeable tourists journey here hungry for the ultimate in Pennsylvania Dutch authenticity: a savory home-cooked meal that some Amish families, overcoming traditional aloofness, have been quietly offering in their determination to survive economically on the farm. From oven-fresh bread to ham loaf, noodles and shoofly pie, the farmhouse repasts can eventually break through to honest conversation and discovery between outsiders and friendly hosts like Elam and Barbara Fisher.

headline.main: Amish Families' Home-Cooked Meals Come Under State Scrutiny

docs.abstract: Pennsylvania Amish families that serve home-cooked meals to tourists as way of supplementing family income come under scrutiny of state health authorities; authorities conclude that this homespun, off-the-books commerce has grown serious enough to require tight health inspections and restaurant-type equipment; this is very sort of modern trapping shunned by Old Order Amish who still journey local roads in horse-and-buggy quaintness that draws tourists in first place; officials question whether some tourists may be at risk of food poisoning; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Like wine cognoscenti, the more knowledgeable tourists journey here hungry for the ultimate in Pennsylvania Dutch authenticity: a savory home-cooked meal that some Amish families, overcoming traditional aloofness, have been quietly offering in their...

docs.lead_paragraph: A panel of federal appeals judges in Atlanta has rejected an effort by a group of managed care companies to derail a proposed class-action lawsuit that was filed against them on behalf of 600,000 doctors. The managed care companies had argued that the doctors' claims had to be decided by arbitration, not in court.

headline.main: U.S. Panel Allows Doctors' Suit Against Health Care Companies

docs.abstract: Panel of federal appeals judges in Atlanta rejects effort by group of managed care companies to derail proposed class-action lawsuit that was filed against them on behalf of 600,000 doctors; managed care companies had argued that doctors' claims had to be decided by arbitration, not in court; lawyers for doctors will ask US Appeals Court to lift order that had stalled litigation; plaintiffs in case say companies have violated contrcts and defrauded doctors in violation of federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, Employee Retirement Income Security Act and state laws; separate group of lawsuits makes similar asserts on behalf of millions of health plan subscribers; Peter Warren, spokesman for California Medical Association, which joined in doctors' suits, says doctors are pleased that circuit court will allow it to continue with lawsuit; Stephanie Kanwit, general counsel of American Association of Health Plans, says ruling is victory for health plans (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 12. Now Playing ''ALL ABOUT THE BENJAMINS,'' starring Ice Cube and Mike Epps. Directed by Kevin Bray (R, 99 minutes). In this fast, violent caper comedy, Ice Cube and Mr. Epps reprise the hip-hop-era, Martin-and-Lewis routing they inaugurated in ''Next Friday.'' There are some funny bits and a few stylish action sequences as the pair, playing a roughneck bounty hunter (Ice Cube) and a motormouth petty con man (Mr. Epps), chase after stolen diamonds, a winning lottery ticket and an international cast of bad guys. But the light comic tone is marred by gruesome, sadistic violence, and the rabid materialism suggested by the title (which refers to $100 bills) has an ugly, cynical edge (A. O. Scott).

docs.lead_paragraph: In a cluster of 40 homes near huge Sebago Lake, whose waters are spookily low and wearing a dismal late-winter collar of mud, residents have enough water in their wells to shower every other day -- and they shower fast. They flush their toilets once a day. Unable to use washing machines in their homes for the past five months, they wait in long lines at coin-operated laundries. For supper, they usually eat sandwiches off paper plates. If they want a proper meal -- the kind that requires washing a lot of dishes -- they drive to a restaurant.

headline.main: Drought Leaves Maine Stoic but Struggling

docs.abstract: Record-setting drought along Eastern Seaboard has made life miserable in rural Maine all winter; Maine Emergency Management Agency says as many as 53,000 households in state that depend on shallow wells are running low on water; many residents flush toilets just once every day, eat on paper plates, shower less frequently and drink only bottled water; experts agree that if exceptional rains do not come this spring, there will be widespread hardship that could lead to health crisis for tens of thousands of rural residents; determining extent of suffering is difficult because people of Maine are stoic and not prone to complaining; Maine's precipitation last year was lowest of 108 years on record; photos; map; graph (M)
